abstract.p: Windows on the World will allow diners to bring their own wine for one week without incurring $20 corkage fee; ONEcps, brasserie being opened by New York Restaurant Group, overlooks Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn; photo (S)

block.p: Windows on the World is giving a weeklong B.Y.O.B. party starting on Saturday. Diners in the restaurant or in the Wild Blue dining room can bring prized bottles of wine to be opened and served without a $20 corkage fee. Kevin Zraly and Glenn Vogt, the wine experts at the restaurants, will suggest complementary dishes. Reservations: (212) 524-7000.

Now that the carpeting and red brocade have been stripped away, Edwardian no longer describes the handsome corner dining room in the Plaza overlooking Grand Army Plaza. Its airy brightness suits its new personality as an American-style brasserie called ONEc.p.s., opening today. Alan Stillman, whose New York Restaurant Group runs it, named it for One Central Park South, an unlikely address for the even-numbered side of the street. David Burke is in charge of the kitchen; Adam Tihany did the design. Their touches of whimsy include a chocolate horse-and-buggy dessert and mammoth hanging red lampshades.
